title: DataViz Makeover 1
description: DataViz Makeover 1 for ISSS608: Visual Analytics
contents:
1. Original Visualisation
Figure 1: Original visualisationData Source
The data visualisation above is created by using data provided by Department of Statistics, Singapore (DOS).
2. Critiques
2.1 Clarity
Chart title is not aligned with the chart content- Title reads as “Merchandise Trade of Top Six Trading Countries, 2019-2020”. However, chart for Japan only reflects 2020 data.
Chart axis is misleading-
y-axis scale differs across each country’s chart. This makes the charts not comparable at first glance, and will mislead users who do not read the graph in detail.
Charts have dual y-axis for imports and exports. The scales for imports and exports within each country’s chart are not synchronized and hence have different ranges. This makes it difficult to compare whether a country is in net export/ import position. This may also be misleading to users who do not read the graph in detail, as they may assume net export/import position simply by seeing the area under the line.

Chart did not specify criteria for which top 6 trading partners is chosen- Considerations such as assessed period and criteria being considered (net trade balance/ import/ export or consider each separately) are not specified. Since the selection criteria is not specified in the chart, we cannot make assumptions on the criteria in this Dataviz exercise. Hence, we should avoid mentioning “top six” in the title.
Presentation may not be the most appropriate depending on what the author is trying to show-
Comparing import and export across time and across countries- since the x-axis and y-axis are not synchronized across each country’s chart, users are unable to do a simple comparison of the area under the line across the charts, for each month.
Comparing net import/ export across time for each country- additional mental subtraction (as scales are not synchronized) and assessment of area under the line required by user to arrive at net export/import for each period.

No commentary provided- reader does not have commentary to understand the main idea of the visualisation.
Does not include data source- reader is unable to verify the data, nor replicate the chart using source data.
Does not specify measurement currency- reader will not know if figures for each country is measured in the same currency. This can be included in the axis information.
2.2 Aesthetics
Different alignments of x-axis- charts of various thickness makes the entire visualisation look disorganised. User is also unable to make a meaningful assessment across each country’s chart for each time period given that the x-axis is not aligned.
Chart title vs country name font size- Font size of title should be larger than the country name as the title will introduce to the user what the chart is about.
Annotations are not used to convey points, leaving the reader to infer the purpose of the graph.
Poor use of colors in the chart- use of area chart with overlap of colors makes it difficult to read.
No tick marks for y-axis values even though it’s on a continuous scale.
Legend title has been left as default (Measure Names), instead of being renamed into something more intuitive and clear to the user.
3. Proposed Design
Sketch
Figure 2: Sketch of proposed designAdvantages of proposed design
3.1 Clarity
Chart title is aligned with the chart content- chart shows only the relevant periods as aligned with title.
Chart axis is aligned across all 6 countries-
y-axis scale is aligned across each country’s chart.
Charts have synchronized axis for imports, exports and net exports/imports.
x-axis width and scale is aligned across each country’s chart.

Proposed chart shows exports, imports and net exports/imports across time for each country- users are able to identify trends across time for the three variables. This also reduces the need for users to manually compute the net export/import.
Chart title provides audience with the big picture, followed by short commentary to provide more context.
Data source is included in chart.
Reference line is added for user to easily identify the demarcation between 2019 and 2020, allowing the user to eyeball the line and bar charts to assess for seasonality effects. Color and line type of reference line is chosen so as to avoid distracting the user.
Measurement currency is specified in the axis so reader will know at one glance.
3.2 Aesthetics
x-axis is aligned across each country’s chart- this makes the visualisation more organised and allows users to compare the trends across time for each country.
Font size for chart title, commentary and chart annotations have been adjusted so as not to divert reader’s attention.
Colors are consistent throughout the dashboard with clear legend on what they represent. Minimal overlapping of colors.
Tick marks added to y-axis scale. Soft gridlines have also been added to the chart to provide reference but not to distract users.
Annotations added to convey points, which includes computation of year-on-year difference in export and imports. This allows users to see at a glance, the trending for exports/ imports.
Default legend title has been renamed to be more representative and clear to the user.

Add source- Using Objects > Text > drag to bottom of dashboard and add: Source: Department of Statistics, Singapore (DOS) (https://www.singstat.gov.sg/) The raw data: https://www.singstat.gov.sg/find-data/search-by-theme/trade-and-investment/merchandise-trade/latest-data
Add author- Using Objects > Text > drag to bottom right of dashboard and add: Dataviz Makeover 1| Stella Loh
6. Observations
There does not appear to be a seasonality pattern in the exports and imports across both years (2019 and 2020), across the six countries.
Hong Kong and Taiwan have remained consistently in the net export and net import position respectively.
Singapore’s net trade with Malaysia is becoming increasing negative (net import position) in 2020, as compared to 2019. This is mainly due to declining exports to Malaysia. Exports have reduced 18.2% Y-O-Y while imports have increased 1.2% Y-O-Y.
Conversely, Singapore’s net trade with United States is becoming increasing positive (net export position) in 2020, as compared to 2019. This is mainly due to increasing exports to United States. Exports have increased 19.3% Y-O-Y while imports have reduced 19.0% Y-O-Y, making Singapore a net exporter for most of 2020.
Imports from Hong Kong are significantly lower than the other five countries.
Exports and imports to/ from Japan remain relatively stable over both years. Both exports and imports with Japan are relatively close and hence the net export or import position is small.
